unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Reducing Type II Errors
question_text:
Which of the following statements is/are true given the following situation?
When performing a two-sample $T$-test, possible ways to reduce the probability of a type II error would be to
I. Increase alpha.
II. Increase sample size.
III. Use a matched pairs experimental design.
solution:
Statement I is true; a higher alpha level requires less evidence to make any changes, making the test more sensitive. Since the test is more sensitive now to detect change, the probability of a type II error is lower.

Statement II is true; larger samples are less variable and therefore more predictable, giving stronger evidence (lower p-value).

Statement III is false; while matched pairs experiments in some situations are preferred, other times they are not practical, and matched pairs design does not necessarily reduce the probability of a type II error.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
